ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of semantics and some other linguistics, I learned a lot about fieldwork methods (starting from no knowledge), and I also performed original extensive research for my first time (I know I'm sort of exposing who I am here, not that I care).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was very impressed with the course given that this was the first time it's been taught.  I liked that we reviewed technical concepts from the readings in class, starting with the basics of topic and focus and then moving to a wide array of topics that might come up during elicitation.  I also liked that we started having brief student presentations of data and that we tasked people with recording data that any of us could then refer to later.  I think that fostered a more collaborative dynamic even though our projects all focus on different topics.  I wish we had started doing that earlier, but I understand that we didn't think of it until a few of weeks in.  I enjoyed the reading responses because they made sure I was understanding the readings enough to have an informed view or critique them, but they also were short and not stressful or overbearing.  With the small class size I thought the low density of assignments was fine because it was easy for me and Professor Dayal to get a sense of my confidence and understanding, but if the class were much bigger I might suggest a reintroduction of the fieldwork report assignment that we got rid of.  I liked that towards the end of the semester once we had developed our own research interests, Professor Dayal was able to make lecture components that addressed the things that we were especially interested in.  In the future, I think the class should set elicitation logistics from the beginning, now that we've learned what works generally.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Discussion was relatively easy virtually because the class was very small.  The most difficult thing over video call was the elicitations, but I don't see a way to improve that while the pandemic still rages.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would.  I'll speak specifically to undergrads because I am one and the situation is probably different for linguistics grad students.  If you have a good understanding of syntax (ie you felt very solid in Syntax one of know that material), you should be alright.  Some semantics might help you get through the readings more easily, and I would certainly recommend it if you're not used a lot fo formal abstraction and set theory sort of stuff.  With that background, this course is a great and accessible way to do some original research: you have the freedom to pick a specific topic, and at the same time you can see what other people do or talk to Veneeta in order to make sure you're on the right track.  The atmosphere of the class is very collaborative, and everybody works together to some extent to try to figure out what's going on in the language of study.  I'd also imagine fieldwork is a new experience for most undergrads - it's a fun exercise and has a way of bringing up interesting linguistic questions you may not have thought to ask.  Keep in mind also that this class doesn't have an ordered curriculum with units of material following each other in succession but is rather a smattering of interconnected topics related to the area of elicitation.
